continuity_notes.name: The Mara
continuity_notes.description: A creature that can only cross to reality through the dreaming of a solitary mind. It can be contained between mirrors and can reproduce itself.
continuity_notes.current_status: Threat to the Kinda and colonists

continuity_notes.name: The Kinda
continuity_notes.description: Indigenous tribe on Deva Loka. Only women speak, they are mutually telepathic, and follow a religion embracing reincarnation.
continuity_notes.current_status: Threatened by colonists and the Mara

continuity_notes.name: Tegan
continuity_notes.current_status: Involved in the conflict on Deva Loka

locations.name: Deva Loka
locations.description: Planet where the story takes place, possibly a lost Earth colony as apples grow there. Previously part of the Sumaran Empire.
locations.current_status: Site of conflict between colonists, Kinda, and the Mara

additional_notes: The story is a subversion of traditional Doctor Who base-under-siege stories. It features pith helmets as fashion victims. The poor special effects of the snake (Mara) are noted as a reason for fanboys rating this story poorly.
bottom_line: One of the best Doctor Who stories ever, astonishingly directed and written as a theatrical piece brimming with allusions and parallels. It's also got a direct and unsilly performance from Simon Rouse, and a thoughtful one from Nerys Hughes. It's not really an allegory, as, unusually for Doctor Who, it's a very original piece of genuine SF.
